name: GCN-4B "Demiurge"
description: The Demiurge — from the Greek δημιουργός, craftsman of worlds, the Platonic figure who shapes raw matter into ordered creation — is the apex gravity constructor and represents the convergence of mining and fabrication into a single closed-loop industrial system. Its excavation system operates twelve plasma arc electrodes across a 6 m face at 10 kW each, but the defining innovation is the downstream Chemistry-On-Demand (COD) processing train that runs in direct series with the excavation head. Disaggregated plasma products are not merely separated by phase or magnetic signature: they are routed through a high-temperature molten-oxide electrolysis (MOX) reactor running at 1600°C, electrochemically splitting silicates and oxides into pure metal streams (Fe, Al, Mg, Ti, Si) and oxygen as a continuous process. The metal streams bypassed for structural use enter an induction-heated rapid solidification unit producing near-net-shape billets at a rate that feeds the construction head without intermediate storage. The construction system is a five-arm mobile gantry supporting wire-arc, laser powder-bed, electron beam, and hot isostatic pressing (HIP) end-effectors simultaneously. This allows the Demiurge to mine regolith, electrolyse it into constituent metals, and additively manufacture finished structural components — all in one unbroken workflow. At 1,350 kg/hr mining and 480 kg/hr construction output the Demiurge can sustain the growth of a full-scale permanent surface installation from raw ground alone. Named for Plato's great craftsman who looked upon the eternal forms and built the material world to match them.
